posts.name: Jan
posts.cooked:
I saw that there is an issue reported that states that Signal Android marks messages as delivered while this is not the case. This issue made me wonder what your experiences are with the reliability (and speed) of message delivery. How reliable are the sent and delivered check marks? Are you using read notifications? How well do they work? How is the consistency over different devices. Do you experience delays in message delivery?
My experience is that Signal is quite reliable nowadays. The message delivery check marks are quite useful. It would be great if Signal automatically tried to resend messages when there was a sent issue. Iâ€™m not using read notifications myself.

posts.name: Joshua Lund
posts.cooked: I just want to point out that the issue you referenced was incorrectly filed in the Signal repo even though it pertains to a fork of Signal that does not use the default configuration.

I have a problem with the reliability of Signal. I hope this thread is ok, the text fits, anyways.

Most of the time, everything works fine.
But sometimes I write someone a message; and it is not delivered at once. Itâ€™s marked as sent, and it takes a while, sometimes up to 20 or 30 minutes, until it is delivered.
I wonder why, so I write a Whatsapp - it gets through at once.

Sometimes I call someone, and while it sounds like a normal try to call,
the recipient doesnâ€™t hear anything. Much later, he sees missed call, at some point.

I was lucky, that the problem occurred, when a friend was with me, in the same room. It was again a situation, where calls and messages have not been delivered at once. So we were able to test a bit.

Sometimes it can be a problem, when an important call does not go through, or a message is delivered way later.

In all tested situations, Whatsapp did work correctly.

What could be the reason for that?

Is the receiving device an Android device? If so, take a look at the following website, it explains why this things can happen and it offers some solutions depending on what device you are using:

Donâ€™t kill my app!

Donâ€™t kill my app!

Hey Android vendors, donâ€™t kill my app!

Have you followed the support article for troubleshooting notifications?

Signal Support

Troubleshooting Notifications

Android iOS Desktop Note: Notifications for reactions will only appear if you choose to display Name and message in the notification. Manage this option in Signal Settings > Notifications. ma...

Re-register for push notifications: iPhone Settings > Notifications > Signal > Re-register Push Notifications > OK.

Doing this^ worked on my roommateâ€™s iPhone 15 Pro.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Make sure background refresh is on for Signal on the receiving device?
If either of you has a linked device, that could help troubleshoot the problem.

Avitus:

Doing this^ worked on my roommateâ€™s iPhone 15 Pro.

I just did that again on all devices of the family. Letâ€™s see.
Letâ€™s hope I donâ€™t have to do it every 4 weeks.

Whatnoww:

Make sure background refresh is on for Signal on the receiving device?

Background app refresh has - on iOS - nothing to do with this problem. The notification system does not require it to be turned on (itâ€™s off for all apps here for many years, too much battery drain).

CueHD:

If either of you has a linked device, that could help troubleshoot the problem.

How that?

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
Oligramm:

Background app refresh has - on iOS - nothing to do with this problem. The notification system does not require it to be turned on (itâ€™s off for all apps here for many years, too much battery drain)

You will need to enable it for Signal to consistently receive messages.

Oligramm:

How that?

You could verify that it is a problem on the receiving client versus a problem on the sending client or the server. If your linked device receives the message, but your iPhone does not, then the problem is certainly on your iPhone.

Whatnoww:

You will need to enable it for Signal to consistently receive messages.

No. This has nothing to do with each other. This is about notification system.
I use Signal for 7 years now, background app refresh was and is always disabled.
The problems occur maybe in 5% of all calls. So I guess there is some problem in Signals connection with APNS

CueHD:

You could verify that it is a problem on the receiving client versus a problem on the sending client or the server. If your linked device receives the message, but your iPhone does not, then the problem is certainly on your iPhone.

Good idea. Never used linked devices. Maybe I will find one to try it out.

posts.cooked:
Oligramm:

No. This has nothing to do with each other. This is about notification system.
I use Signal for 7 years now, background app refresh was and is always disabled.

Then you shouldâ€™ve never received notifications for the last 7 years. The Signal app has to query the server for queued messages waiting to be delivered. By turning background refresh off, youâ€™re not going to get notifications.

Oligramm:

Good idea. Never used linked devices. Maybe I will find one to try it out.

Note you can only link a phone to a computer. Linking multiple phones isnâ€™t supported.

Avitus:

Note you can only link a phone to a computer. Linking multiple phones isnâ€™t supported.

An iPad can also be a linked device.

Sorry, but that is complete nonsense.
You should really read how the APNS works. No social media app needs background app refresh.

People, please do not spread fake news here.
